entries.content: When anticipating disinterest (e.g., on a cold call), offer the prospect an easy out upfront to build trust and lower defenses.
entries.notes: Used phrases like 'you're gonna hate me actually this is actually a sales call so I'm not sure if you want to hang up now or let me have 30 seconds'.

entries.content: You're gonna hate me, this is a sales call. Feel free to hang up or give me 30 seconds.
entries.notes: An upfront, disarming way to address the nature of the call.

entries.content: After acknowledging the sales nature of the call, softly probe to see if anything resonates or if there's a slight opening.
entries.notes: Used phrases like 'you're probably going to tell me you can't relate... has something resonated?'

entries.content: Has something resonated with you though?
entries.notes: A gentle probe to see if the initial pitch, however brief, sparked any interest.

entries.content: If the prospect doesn't immediately hang up or says 'it's fine', probe for potential pain points to diagnose the reason for potential interest or lack thereof.
entries.notes: Asked 'if there was one thing could do better what would it be?' or 'are they [sales people] frustrating you?'

entries.content: Just one last question, if there was one thing [related to your business/role] you could do better, what would it be?
entries.notes: A soft diagnostic question to uncover potential needs or frustrations.

entries.content: Are they [e.g., your sales team] frustrating you? Just be honest, because then I know it's worth calling.
entries.notes: A direct but honest probe to diagnose if a specific pain point exists that warrants further conversation.

focus_area: Handling "Not Interested": Probe softly, diagnose if disinterest or timing
